member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ChartNode.FreeDD(System.Object@)
member.summary: Helper method for disposal of the given DrawData. Set the reference to null.
member.remarks: Intentionally not checking validity of the device or chart reference. It's left to caller, so that we do not have to do the checks on each call. Might not be the proper place for this, but this is common ancestor to just about everything, and has the chart reference.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Annotations.AnnotationBase.Anchor
member.summary: Rotation uses this point as a center point. Tells where to place the anchored point within the control area. For X dimension, value 0 represents left coordinate of the object and 1 right coordinate. For Y dimension, value 0 represents top coordinate of the object and 1 bottom coordinate. To define anchor point outside the object area, define values outside range 0...1.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute imaginary axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where ImgR(z(d)) = j(X/Z0).
member.remarks: See http://care.iitd.ac.in/People/Faculty/bspanwar/crl713/smith_chart_basics.pdf page 145.
member.param: Absolute imaginary axis value to normalize to -1..1 range.
member.returns: Normalized imaginary axis value, in range -1..1. Values can be larger, of course, but then they reside outside the unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormReal(System.Double)
member.summary: Normalize the absolute real axis value. Means z(d) => r+jx, where RealR(z(d)) = R/Z0.

remarks.para: No reason to keep NormReal and NormImg separate, except that not sure if there will be changes later.

member.param: Absolute real axis value to normalize.
member.returns: Normalized real axis value. Normalized to range 0..1. Values outside this range do not fit in the Unit circle.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsImg(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the normalized imaginary value to absolute scale.
member.param: Normed imaginary axis value to convert back to absolute values.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsReal(System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the normalized real value to absolute scale.
member.param: >Normed RealValue axis value to convert back to absolute value.

member.summary: Converts normed smith view value to absolute value. Normed value 1 matches the given absolute reference value.
member.param: Smith values imaginary or real part to convert.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.AbsToNorm(System.Double)
member.summary: Converts absolute smith view value to normed value. Normed value 1 is at the center of the chart. Normed value 1 matches the given absolute reference value.
member.param: Smith values imaginary or real part to convert

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormImgToRad(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the Normed imaginary part (normalized reactance) to the grid circle radius in screen space.
member.param: Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1).
member.returns: Radius of the Imaginary-circle in screen space, if proper UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the Imaginary-cicle radus in relative unit circle space.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormRealToRad(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the Normed RealValue-part (normalized resistance) to the grid circle radius in screen space.
member.param: Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)
member.returns: Radius of the RealValue-circle in screen space, if proper UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the RealValue-cicle radius in relative unit circle space.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.RadToNormImg(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the Imaginary-circle radius in screen space to the normed imaginary-part (normalized reactance), if valid UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the imaginary-circle radius is expected to be in relative UnitCircle space.
member.remarks: This is the reverse operation of NormImgToRad method.
member.param: Radius of the Imaginary-circle radius. Value in screen space, if UnitRadius is given, and in UnitCircle space if not.
Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)
member.returns: Normed Imaginary-axis value matching the given radius.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.RadToNormReal(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Convert the RealValue-circle radius in screen space to the normed RealValue-part (normalized resistance), if valid UnitRadius is given. Otherwise the RealValue-circle radius is expected to be in relative UnitCircle space.
member.remarks: This is the reverse operation of NormImgToRad method.
member.param: Radius of the RealValue-circle radius. Value in screen space, if UnitRadius is given, and in UnitCircle space if not.
Radius of the unit circle in screen space. Defaults to 1 (radius of 1)
member.returns: Normed RealValue-axis value matching the given radius.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.NormValueToUCValue(Arction.Wpf.Charting.PointSmith)
member.summary: Converts normed smith value value pair to UC coordinates

remarks.para: The real and imaginary values are normed values of the RealValue and ImgValue axis. Circle radiuses mathing those values area calculated, the intersection point of the circles area calculated in normed unit-circle space, and then returned. The other intersection point of the circles is at point 1,0 (in UC space), the Y-component of the RealValue circle center point is 0 (center is at X-Axis), and the X-component of the Imaginary circle is 1. See http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Circle-CircleIntersection.html.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisSmithBase.UCValueToNormedValue(Arction.Wpf.Charting.PointFloat)
member.summary: Convert normed coordinates in unit circle space (Origo at the center of the circle) to matching normed real and imaginary values.
member.returns: PointFloat with Normed RealValue (on X-parameter) and Imaginary (on Y-parameter) components, matching the given coordinates.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisY.Fit(System.Double,System.Boolean@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fit axis min and max to show all series values
member.param: Margin to leave between axis minimum or maximum and series values, in percents of min...max range
Method sets this true if Y axis minimum or maximum has changed
If true, all series points are searched, resulting to better accuracy, but with a cost raised CPU load.
Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting
member.remarks: For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behaviour.

members.member:
Fit axis min and max to show all series values, while keeping the range withing given limits
Margin to leave between axis minimum or maximum and series values, in percents of min...max range Method sets this true if Y axis minimum or maximum has changed If true, all series points are searched, resulting to better accuracy, but with a cost raised CPU load. Ignore zeros values from logarithmic axis fitting For logarithmic axis, call Fit method with pixel range, for appropriate behaviour. /// Minimum limit. If detected minimum is below limit minimum, the limit applies Maximum limit. If detected minimum is below limit minimum, the limit applies

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesEventMarkerVerticalPosition.TrackSeries
member.summary: Track the series. The Y value is solved from X value. You can use this only for series implementing ITrackable interface Not applicable in X axis scrolling modes Scrolling, Stepping, Sweeping (monitoring modes). The resolver data is not valid for performance reasons. You should insert a marker as AtYValue in monitoring mode and convert it as TrackSeries when entering data review mode. Works only on series implementing ITrackable.

member.summary: Render device is not available anymore

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.RenderInvalidCall
member.summary: Rendering caused invalid call exception. Possibly caused by updating chart from a separate thread without synchronizing it with main program thread. You should use BeginInvoke or Invoke methods for synchronization.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.RenderDeviceSurfaceHasWrongSize
member.summary: The renderer created a drawing surface whose size does not match the parent control's client size.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.InvalidSeriesResolverDataWithSeriesEventMarker
member.summary: Series data X coordinate to Y coordinate resolver data has become invalid, because points have been added. Do not use markers as 'TrackSeries' with X axis monitoring monitoring scroll modes. Instead, you should define them as 'AtYValue' and convert them 'TrackSeries' when opening data in review mode, and set the scroll mode to 'None'.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.SeriesIsNotTrackable
member.summary: You are requesting a tracking operation on a series, that is not trackable (does not implement ITrackable)

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.SampleFormatMismatch
member.summary: Samples use different format than you try to use

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.DataPointTypeMismatch
member.summary: Series has been configured to use different data point type than you are trying to use

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.FastVertexFormatIsNotSupported
member.summary: Fast vertices data is tried to be used, but current graphics adapter does not support them.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.InvalidLogAxisOperation
member.summary: The selected feature can't be used with logarithmic axis

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.ShaderModel3NotSupported
member.summary: Shader model 3 is not supported by the GPU some parts of the chart are cannot drawn as intended.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.BeginUpdateEndUpdateCallCountMismatch
member.summary: EndUpdate() is called more often than BeginUpdate().

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ErrorType.InvalidSaveFileFormat
member.summary: Invalid save file format. E.g. one can only save XY graph as vector.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.ExtensionsClass.IsValidRef(Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Checks if the given CHART reference is valid, warns (if warning enabled) if it's not, or if the m_rd is null. Reason for this is that we're using the m_chart != null in quite a lot of situation protecting the m_rd ref, and skip DD disposes if it's null. Using this we get the knowledge of where the memory freeing might have been skipped at.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate.HandleWMDPIChangedEvent(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.Boolean@)
member.summary:
Event handler for DPI changes. Called when process is per-monitor aware and DPI changes either because the window is moved from screen to other or the user selected new DPI. Stores the new per-monitor DPI (that is not yet used anywhere) and re-positions the window (which is kind of client applications responsibility and thus might be better not to do).
User (client app) can prevent the automatic resize by use of OnDPIChanged event.
member.remarks: For more information see WM_DPICHANGED message documentation. https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/dn312083%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
member.param: Rect specifying the new suggested position and size of the window.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate.GetDPICoeff(Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate)
member.summary: Getter of the current DPI coefficient for the current monitor.
member.remarks:
Currently depends only on m_dpiSystemDefault, not on UpdateDPIFromMonitor or m_fDPIFromMonitor. This might of course change later.
Moved the implementation in effec to DpiToCoef method.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate.UpdateDpiHelper(Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat)
member.summary: Updates DPI helpers system DPI factor information from the given parameter.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.LightningChartUltimate.UpdateDPI
member.summary: Updates internal DPI members from monitor data. Skips update if not required and/or should not be done. After the call m_fDPIXCoeff and m_fDPIYCoeff have valid values.
member.remarks: Delivers the information to the engine. Currently relies on GetDPICoeff that uses m_dpiSystemDefault and that does not change currently, so for now there is no reason to call this but once, or after engine changes to report it there. Later the use might change however because of the live reaction to DPI / Resolution changes, that we do not yet support properly, as we have no reliable way of ascertaining the new system dpi.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Series3D.SurfaceSeries3DBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.Wpf.Charting.BitmapAntialiasOptions,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width x Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
Sets NegativeInfinity when bitmap pixel has alpha = 0.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.HighLowSeriesBase.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries
member.summary: Freeform point line series. You can define the line and points style. Add points with AddPoints method.
member.remarks:
The points don't have to be in successive order by X value. If they are used in successive order in your application, you should use PointLineSeries or SampleDataSeries instead for optimal performance. Freeform point line series causes significantly higher CPU/GPU load than other line series types, when the series point count is high.
Note that the first array is not necessarily the first point of the series, as the Points array is a circular buffer.

member.summary: Limit point count by dropping oldest points. The point count is limited to PointCountLimit.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.PointCountLimit
member.summary: Point count limit. If you add points more than limited count, first points are automatically removed. The limiter only applies if PointCountLimitEnabled is true.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.FreeformPointLineSeries.OldestPointIndex
member.summary: Gets the index of oldest point in Points array. When PointCountLimitEnabled is true, the Points array is used as an circular point buffer. This is 0 always when PointCountLimitEnabled is false. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is 0: Read from index 0 till PointCount-1. To read Points, when OldestPointIndex is > 0: First read from OldestPointIndex till PointCountLimit-1. Then read from index 0 till OldestPointIndex-1.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetValuesData(System.Double[][],Arction.Wpf.Charting.IntensityGridValuesDataOrder)
member.summary: Sets values. Doesn't update the Data array contents itself. Very handy to make the chart render fast when the data is being changed frequently, especially with IntensityGridSeries' PixelRendering mode enabled.
member.param: Data. The alignment must be M x N, all rows must be of equal length.
Jagged array order dimensions order. Is first array dimension columns and second dimension rows, or vice versa
member.remarks: If SetColors method is used too, the data array dimensions and order must be same than with SetValuesData

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.InvalidateValuesDataOnly
member.summary: Invalidate values data only. Use this together with Optimization = DynamicValuesData. Does not update the geometry to the GPU when not needed, allowing significantly faster rendering.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetSize(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set grid size, both X and Y at same time. If you already have a large existing data, using this method is faster than setting SizeX and SizeY separately.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetHeightDataFromBitmap(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Drawing.Bitmap,Arction.Wpf.Charting.BitmapAntialiasOptions)
member.summary: Create data based on bitmap file contents. Data array will have dimensions of the bitmap Width x Height. Use options to reduce resolution and smooth it if needed. Height data of is calculated for each pixel from R, G, and B sum. 0 (black) will have the minimum value, and maximum value is obtained from 3*255 (white). If bitmap has alpha value of 0, the data is set to -INF, and the value is not drawn.
member.param: Bitmap resolution decrement and smoothing options. Give null to use pure bitmap data only.
member.returns: True if data was successfully filled, else false.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.IntensitySeriesBase.SetColorsData(System.Int32[][],Arction.Wpf.Charting.IntensityGridValuesDataOrder)
member.summary: Sets colors. Doesn't update the Data array contents itself. Very handy to make the chart render fast when the colors are being changed frequently, especially with IntensityGridSeries' PixelRendering mode enabled.
member.param: Data. The alignment must be M x N, all rows must be of equal length.
Jagged array order dimensions order. Is first array dimension columns and second dimension rows, or vice versa
member.remarks: Only works when Fill = FromSourcePoints
If SetValuesData method is used too, the data array dimensions and order must be same than with SetColors

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.PointLineSeries.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SeriesXY.SampleDataSeries.ScrollModePointsKeepLevel
member.summary: Tells how often the draw data is cleared when using X axis scroll mode. Valid range is 1...100 1 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 1/10 scroll page. Use this when there's not much memory available. 100 frees the draw data and the reconstucts the draw data after every 100/10 = 10 pages. Use this when smooth scroll with high FPS is important. Reserves some extra memory.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.PureDevice
member.summary: True if optimal pure device mode is supported.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.FastVertexFormat
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports fast vertex format. Fast vertices are not available for old graphics adapters. If false, the rendering performance is not optimal, since slower vertex formats must be used. Getting a new graphics adapter is strongly recommended, ensure it is at least DirectX 10 level, for best performance.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.HardwareVertexProcessing
member.summary: True if your graphics adapter supports vertex processing in hardware (GPU). If false, the vertex calculation has to be done in software (computer CPU), and the performance is not optimal.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.ShaderModel3
member.summary: True if shader model 3 is supported. Both vertex and pixel shaders are format 3 or greater.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.IndexBuffers32Bit
member.summary: True if 32-bit index buffers are supported. If only 16-index buffers are supported, returns false. In this case the 3D surfaces may be limited into smaller sizes.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.TexturesSizesNonPowerOf2
member.summary: Limited support for textures which size is not power of two.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.D2Dv11Supported
member.summary: True if D2D v1.1 is supported, false if not. The v1.1 is required for HW text rendering on DX11. On DX9 this is always false.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderDeviceInfo.DpiAware
member.summary: True if sofware is DPI aware

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings
member.summary: Rendering settings, that can be given as chart constructor parameter. Speeds up creating of the chart, if non-default values are given, preventing the chart rendering engine to be re-created several times.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.WaitforVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn. Enabling this may improve performance especially in slow computers.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.EffectCaching
member.summary: Effect caching. HLSL shaders are compiled into streams, enabling very fast chart resizing. It's recommeded to keep this enabled. But in Windows XP, disabling this property may give significant decrement in delay when rendering the chart first time. Disabling this will cause flickering when resizing the chart.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.RenderingSettings.D2DEnabled
member.summary: Temporary debug setting for disabling D2D system and text rendering on DX11.

member.summary: Constructor for Form designer list editor

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement
member.summary:
The base class for SVG elements. It represents some part of an SVG document, either an element (rect, circle etc) or a text item. Duties include:
Maintains a list of child elements and a list of attributes.
Writes itself and its children to an Xml document.
Reads itself and its children from an Xml document.

member.summary: Given a document and a current node, read this element from the node.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement.WriteXmlElements(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an XML document and a parent node, write out this node and its descendants as XmlElements.
member.param: A node, or null if this element is to be the root element

member.summary: A simple ToString() for use in debugging.

member.summary: Get a string that contains a complete SVG document. XML version, DOCTYPE etc are included.
member.param: Should usually be set true. Causes the XML output to be optimized so that long attributes like styles and transformations are represented with entities.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory
member.summary: Static methods to produce/write/copy Svg documents reside in this class.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.LoadFromXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Given an xml document and (optionally) a particular element to start from, read the xml nodes and construct a tree of objects. Xml tags that do not correspond to a particular class will be represented by an . This means that literally any XML input can be read in and written out, even if it has nothing to do with Svg. More usefully, it means that new and unsupported tags and attributes will be represented in the SvgElement tree and written out correctly even if SvgNet does not understand them.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CompressXML(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary:
Helper function to compress long xml attributes into entities.
This would work on any XML, it is not SVG specific, so it should eventually be in some 'xml tools' class.
member.returns: A string of entities which can be inserted into the DOCTYPE when the document is written.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.RecCompXML(System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Collections.Hashtable,System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Xml.XmlElement,System.Int32@)
member.param: Map of attribute to number of occurrences -- could be used to improve algorithm
Map of attribute to entity name
Number that is incremented to provide new entity names

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgFactory.CloneElement(Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElement)
member.summary: Create a complete deep copy of the given tree of SvgElement objects. A new set of elements is created, and if the attributes are cloneable they are deep-copied too. Since strings and all SvgType classes are cloneable, the new tree is independant of the old.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgStyledTransformedElement
member.summary: This is an SvgElement that can have a CSS style and an SVG transformation list. It contains special properties to make reading and setting the style and the transformation easier. All SVG elements that actually represent visual entities or groups of entities are SvgStyledTransformedElements.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.IGraphics
member.summary:
An interface that contains exactly the same methods as the GDI+ Graphics object. If your drawing routines draw to an IGraphics interface, then you can supply either a GdiGraphics object to render to the screen, or an object to render to an SVG file.
It's a pity that Graphics is a sealed class. Otherwise there'd be no need to have this interface or the class; we could simply derive a class from Graphics to do SVG output.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.GdiGraphics
member.summary: An IGraphics implementation that simply passes every call through to a GDI+ Graphics object.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGdiNotImpl
member.summary: Exception thrown when a GDI+ operation is attempted on an IGraphics implementor that does not support the operation. For instance, SvgGraphics does not support any of the MeasureString methods.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics
member.summary:
This is an IGraphics implementor that builds up an SVG scene. Use it like a regular Graphics object, and call WriteXMLString to output SVG. In this way, whatever you would normally draw becomes available as an SVG document.
SvgGraphics has to do quite a lot of work to convert GDI instructions to SVG equivalents. Some things are approximated and slight differences will be noticed. Also, in several places GDI+ does not do what it is supposed to (e.g. arcs of non-circular ellipses, truncating bitmaps). In these cases SvgGraphics does do the right thing, so the result will be different.
Some GDI instructions such as MeasureString are meaningless in SVG, usually because there is no physical display device to refer to. When such a method is called an exception is thrown.
Many parameters used by GDI have no SVG equivalent -- for instance, GDI allows some fine control over how font hints are used. This detailed information is thrown away.
Some aspects of GDI that can be implemented in SVG are not. The most important omission is that only solid brushes are supported.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.WriteSVGString
member.summary: Get a string containing an SVG document. The very heart of SvgGdi. It calls WriteSVGString on the at the root of this SvgGraphics and returns the resulting string.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawString(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.Brush,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented.
In general, DrawString functions work, but it is impossible to guarantee that an SVG renderer will have a certain font and draw it in the same way as GDI+.
SVG does not do word wrapping and SvgGdi does not emulate it yet (although clipping is working). The plan is to wait till SVG 1.2 becomes available, since 1.2 contains text wrapping/flowing attributes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.MeasureString(System.String,System.Drawing.Font,System.Drawing.SizeF,System.Drawing.StringFormat,System.Int32@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: This method is implemented and produces a result which is often correct, but it is impossible to guarantee because 'MeasureString' is a fundamentally inapplicable to device independent output like SVG.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawIcon(System.Drawing.Icon,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Implemented. The DrawIcon group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.DrawImage(System.Drawing.Image,System.Drawing.PointF)
member.summary:
Implemented. The DrawImage group of functions emulate drawing a bitmap by creating many SVG rect elements. This is quite effective but can lead to a very big SVG file. Alpha and stretching are handled correctly. No antialiasing is done.
The GDI+ documentation suggests that the 'Unscaled' functions should truncate the image. GDI+ does not actually do this, but SvgGraphics does.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.AddMetafileComment(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Does nothing. Should perhaps insert a comment into the SVG XML output, but is this really analogous to a metafile comment.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.HandleBrush(System.Drawing.Brush)
member.summary:
When a GDI instruction with a brush parameter is called, there can be a lot we have to do to emulate the brush. The aim is to return a style that represents the brush.
Solid brush is very easy.
Linear grad brush: we ignore the blend curve and the transformation (and therefore the rotation parameter if any) Hatch brush:
Other types of brushes are too hard to emulate and are rendered pink.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.ChangeWhenAllPointsOnLine(System.Drawing.PointF[])
member.summary: MS Visio do ugly things if a line with clip should be drawn and all points on line are on the same x or y position. When the giben points are on a real horizontal or vertical line this function changes the first point for 0.0001.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgGdi.SvgGraphics.MatrixStack
member.summary:
This class is needed because GDI+ does not maintain a proper scene graph; rather it maintains a single transformation matrix which is applied to each new object. The matrix is saved and reloaded when 'begincontainer' and 'endcontainer' are called. SvgGraphics has to emulate this behaviour.
This matrix stack caches it's 'result' (ie. the current transformation, the product of all matrices). The result is recalculated when necessary.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTextElement
member.summary: Represents a text element. The SVG text element is unusual in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements (other elements like this are title, desc, and tspan). SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgElements.SvgTspanElement
member.summary: Represents a tspan element. The tspan element is unique in that it expects actual XML text nodes below it, rather than consisting only of attributes and child elements. SvgTextElement therefore has to be serialized to XML slightly differently.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.SvgNet.SvgTypes.SvgStyle.Clone
member.summary: Creates a new style, but does not do a deep copy on the members in the style. Thus if any of these are not strings, they meay be left referred to by more than one style or element.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.LinearFitSolveFactors(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double@,System.Double@)
member.summary: Calculate linear fit from given points. Makes best fit with Least Square regression method. A line equation is y = k*x + b, that is, y = gradient * x + coefficient
member.param: Coefficient, Y value of intersection where X = 0
member.remarks: X values array lenght must be equal to Y values array length

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.LinearRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Calculate linear line fit for given points
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.PolynomialRegression(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[]@)
member.summary: Calculate polymial line fit. Calculates polynomial factors, and uses these factors to solve Y values based on given X value array.
member.param: X values that are used to calculate the factors. This is the point set where the regression line is fitted to.
Y values that are used to calculate the factors. Length must be equal to xInFactorization length.
X values whose Y values are to be solved, using the factors
Order of polynomial. Usually more than 3 shouldn't be used
Polynomial result factors, length = order+1. For example, when having order 2, you can plot line with equation: Y = factors[0] + factors[1]*X + factors[2]*X^2
member.returns: Fitted Y values, the length equals to xValuesToFit length. Returns null if failed.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.MathRoutines.AlignedLineCircleIntersection(System.Collections.Generic.List{Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat}@,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat,System.Double,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat,Arction.RenderingDefinitions.PointFloat)
member.summary: Finds intersections (0..2) between circle and an axis aligned line _segment_. The found points are added to the list. Order of the endpoints does not matter.
member.remarks: Algorithm could easilly have bool property that would allow reporting of actual line, not line segment intersection. The detection algorighm is quite stupid, sorry for that.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.D2DEnabled
member.summary: Determines if the D2D system is used or not. Text rendering does not work on DX11 without D2D. This is intended only as Debug measure at this time, and the property will be removed later.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.AntiAliasLevel
member.summary: Anti-aliasing factor. 1 = no anti-aliasing. The larger the value, the smoother the image will be, but at steep cost of performance on some display adapters. Only objects having AntiAlias property will be anti-aliased, if it's set to 'Normal'

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType2D
member.summary: Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines. Applicaple only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 px are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineAAType3D
member.summary: Anti-aliasing type of single pixel width anti-aliased lines. Applicaple only on DX11 and when AntiAliasLevel is above 1. Lines thicker than 1 px are rendered using triangles, and use triangle drawing AA system. ALAA option produces generally best looking line and is faster than QLAA. There is some problems with ALAA with Warp though.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.LineOffset
member.summary: Debug Line offset of the DX11 line drawing. LightningChart internally uses coordinate system where the coordinate points to the center of the pixel. Meaning that screen coordinate (0,0) is at the center of the top-left pixel. In DX9 this is the same. In DX11 the point (0,0) is at the top-left corner of the top-left pixel, and the center of the pixel is at point (0.5, 0.5). The points are moved by this offset in DX11 engine, so that the chart can use the same coordinate system with all engines. The default value of (0.5, 0.5) is the "correct" one, but it can be modified by this property.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.WaitForVSync
member.summary: Wait for next refresh, V-Sync. If the computer is fast enough, disabling this can give higher refresh rate than the screen refresh rate is. By disabling this, rendering does not wait next screen refresh turn.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.InvokeRenderingInUIThread
member.summary: Use thread safe updates to force the control draw itself though Invoke. Enabling this may cause slower updates, and should not be used in applications running without auxliary threads updating the chart data or properties. Alternatively, you can use Invoke method of your parent form or control. You should always update the chart data from by Invoking in application side.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.RenderOptionsCommon.UpdateOnResize
member.summary: Update chart always when resizing control.

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D
member.summary:
Camera in 3D.
Location and orientation
Cameara location and orientation in is defined in relation to the target by RotationX, RotationY and RotationZ properties. RotationX and RotationY properties define the camera location as euler angles, with order X-Y. RotationZ defines camera orientation by defining up-direction as rotation around rotated worlds Z-axis (on XY plane), with 0 rotation producing up direction of Y=1, X=0.
The possible values can be limited by the use of RotationXMinimum and RotationXMaximum properties for X axis rotation, and the respective properties for Y and Z axis.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_vUp
member.summary: Worlds UP direction vector. In effect, controlled through Z-property.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_vLocation
member.summary: Camera location in relation to.area center (m_Target)

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.m_bMatrixUpdateDisabled
member.summary: Flag to disable matrix updates. Usefull for internal euler angle modifications.

member.summary: Clean up any resources being used.
member.param: true if managed resources should be disposed, otherwise false.

member.summary: Same as setting RotationX, RotationY and RotationZ properties separately. Allows easier setting of the properties and is faster than separate setting of the properties.
member.remarks: Note that using this the property change events come before actual view changes.

member.param: Horizontal rotation in degrees. Negative to left.
Vectical rotation in degrees. Negative to down.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.SetCamLocation(SharpDX.Mathematics.Vector3,System.Boolean,SharpDX.Mathematics.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets camera location. Sets the X and Y rotation properties based on given camera direction and calclulates the Z rotation from ReverseUp parmater and current Z-rotation property.
member.remarks: Causes a single ChildPropertyChanged call and view matrix recalculation. Will skip the "normal" view matrix generation if the properties do not produce valid enough result.
member.param: the new location of the camera
the new UP direction of the camera

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.View3D.Camera3D.CamLocationToXYZ(SharpDX.Mathematics.Vector3)
member.summary: Converts camera location, target and up vectors back to X and Y properties that produce the same values.
member.remarks: Note that the returned value is not really Vector, just a tuplet of floats.
member.returns: Camera rotation parameters matching the given values as a list of doubles. The order of the parameters is X, Y, Z, in radians. There are allways 3 valud in the list.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewRound.ViewRoundBase.FixZoomRectFromMouseLocations(System.Drawing.RectangleF@)
member.summary: Modifies the rect for the use in zooming calculations. Makes proper aspect ratio corrections to a rect, forces it to have positive size, and takes m_bRectangleZoomAboutOrigin into account.

remarks.para: The returned rect's size is allways positive in both directions. The start point corner can not be determined from the rect alone. This is due the use of the rect in drawing operations, where the contents get culled otherwise.
The aspect ratio following allways modifies the StopX or StopY parameter, not the start point, unless the ZoomCenteredOnOrigin (etc) is enabled.
The input rect's size CAN BE NEGATIVE in either direction.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewRound.ViewRoundBase.FixAspectRatio(System.Drawing.RectangleF@,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Fixes aspect ratio to match the view aspect ratio. Keeps X,Y coords if Center property is false (default), negative sizes allowed (suggestged in some cases). Does not reduce the rect size, only increases it.
member.remarks: Center property can be used to increase the size on both directions.
member.param: If true, keep the rect center in place. Ohtherwise the X/Y is kept in place (which is not necessarilly the left/top)
Increases the size same amount on both directions.

member.summary: Gridline constructor. Not that even thought this takes the tree reference, one must still add the item to some node (GridLine) as child for the item to be entered into the tree.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.CreateInverseOf(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine)
member.summary: Generates inverse gridline over X axis. Applicaple only for imaginary lines.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.InverseY
member.summary: Inverses basic settings as inverse over X axix. Applicaple only for imaginary lines. Note that the angles of the line must be positive. Othwerwise fix this method.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.UpdateCircleData
member.summary: Update initial arc definitions, radius and center

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.CalcRad
member.summary: Calculates the radius of the circle/arc in "UC" values. To get the actual screen coordinate distance, multiply with the radius of the axis.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.CalcCenter
member.summary: Calculates the center of the arc/circle in UC coords. Call evrey time the arc radius (in UC) changes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.UpdateInitialPoints
member.summary: Updates UC values of StartPoint, EndPoint and CirclePoint. Needs to be called after CutPoint (value) changes.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.UpdateInitialAngles
member.summary: Updates initial Start / End angles. No view limitation made yet, based just on Start-/EndPoint. Call if initial Start/end points change. Updates the current start/end angles as well.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.ViewRectOptimizeInternal(System.Drawing.RectangleF)
member.summary: Updates the arc definitions based on the view rect, to reduce the amount of drawing.
member.remarks: Current implementation of the ClipToCircle is not really that good.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.AddChild(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Internall child addition to the tree. The new gridline is of inverse type than this, with given value. Does not set the child level. That must be set by the caller.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.AddInverseChild(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine)
member.summary: Creates a new inverse child gridline of the given imaginary line. Can not be called for real lines. Uses given lines values for determining the initial angles and points so we do not need to actually calculate them. The given child must have it's values already calculated.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.Intersection(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an intersection with this circle and a circle of iverse type of the given normed smith value. Returned value in screen coordinates.
member.returns: Screen coordinates of the intersection of the two circles.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLine.CutPoint
member.summary: Point where the line is cut, set by DetermiGridLinePoints. It is the point where this circle crosses with parent -> We can recalculate it here as well.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_bRadChanged
member.summary: Defines if the changed radius has been taken into account in calculations.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_dLimitFactor
member.summary: Factor of the given limit distance for determining the cutpoint. Cutting distance C is calculated by C = F*S + I, where I is this, S = m_dLimitDistance and F = m_dLimitFactor.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_dLimitInc
member.summary: Increment to the cutting disntance. Cutting distance C is calculated by C = F*S + I, where I is this, S = m_dLimitDistance and F = m_dLimitFactor.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_dLimitDistance
member.summary: Average distance of the gridlines where they are furthest away from each others.

member.name: F:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewSmith.GridLineTree.m_dLimitSkip
member.summary: Number of gridline levels to skip when searching for next lines endpoint.

member.summary: Defines if the lines are to be clipped in to the circle area or not.

member.summary: Defines if the system uses normed or absolute values. Makes difference in value rounding

member.name: T:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer
member.summary: Persistent series rendering layer. Series can be rendered in a bitmap layer and the actual series freed. Saves a lot of memory, CPU and GPU resources, especially when rendering hundreds or thousands of series. The layer itself is rendered in the chart just before line series objects.
member.example: Consider a typical use case of FFT monitoring, where one data line series is collected periodically and added in the layer in full. The layer shows historic information of thousands of FFT strips. By using the persistent series layer, each series has millions of points, and the dozens of new strips can be added every second. By freeing the series itself after rendering it to the layer, the total memory consumption does not rise, and the system won't run out of memory even if the monitoring lasts several weeks.

member.name: M:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.PersistentSeriesRenderingLayer.#ctor(Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.ViewXY,Arction.Wpf.Charting.Axes.AxisX)
member.param: X axis, whose series will be used in this layer

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.ViewXY.DropOldSeriesData
member.summary: Automatically deletes series data, whose x value is less than X-axis minimum. By setting this true, the performance is much better in real-time monitoring applications.

member.name: P:Arction.Wpf.Charting.Views.ViewXY.ViewXY.DropOldEventMarkers
member.summary: Automatically deletes chart event markers and series event markers, whose x value is less than X-axis minimum. By setting this true, the performance is much better in real-time monitoring applications.
